Scheme 3 Host-guest assemblies of anchoring molecular catalysts of CO2 reduction onto CuInS2/ZnS quantum dots for robust photocatalytic syngas production in water Ying-Yi Ren Investigation Writing – original draft Wu Xia Validation Bo-Yi Deng Visualization Jing Liu Validation Feng Wang Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Key Laboratory of Materials Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Huazhong University of Science and Technology) of Ministry of Education, Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure, Hubei Engineering Research Center for Biomaterials and Medical Protective Materials, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, PR China Key Laboratory of Materials Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Huazhong University of Science and Technology) of Ministry of Education Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure Hubei Engineering Research Center for Biomaterials and Medical Protective Materials School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430074 PR China Key Laboratory of Materials Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Huazhong University of Science and Technology) of Ministry of Education, Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure, Hubei Engineering Research Center for Biomaterials and Medical Protective Materials, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Simultaneously fulfilling CO2-to-CO and 2H+-to-H2 reactions in water via photocatalyst represents an alternative to produce syngas driven by solar energy. To this end, photocatalyst having ability of simultaneously producing CO and H2 with controllable ratio should be exploited. In this work, we report a self-assembly photocatalyst C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS quantum dots (QDs) that enabling to produce syngas robustly in CO2-saturated water under visible light irradiation. C1 is a molecular catalyst of linking an adamantine moiety to [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl (TPA = tris (2-pyridylmethyl) amine), while CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs are semiconductor QDs with structure of CuInS2 core and ZnS shell and containing β-cyclodextrin (CD) on the surface. The C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs assemblies form by anchoring molecular cobalt catalyst C1 onto cyclodextrin (CD) modified CuInS2/ZnS quantum dots (CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs) based on host-guest interaction between adamantine in C1 and cyclodextrin in the QDs. In which, C1 functions a molecular catalytic center mainly for CO2 reduction, and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs functions as both a light harvester and a hydrogen production center. The C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs system maintains syngas production activity over 200 h, and produces 184.21 μmol syngas with a CO/H2 ratio of 0.74 (ca. 2:3), exhibiting obvious advantages of syngas production efficiency in comparison to the non-assembled system and pristine CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs system. Mechanism studies revealed that photoinduced electron transfer between CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs and C1 occurs. The host-guest interaction improves syngas production activity and stability as well as plays positive role on stability of the molecular catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Artificial photosynthesis Self-assembly Host-guest chemistry CO2 reduction Syngas production 1 Introduction Syngas (synthesis gas), a gaseous mixture of carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen (H2), is a crucial feedstock in petrochemical industry [1,2]. Syngas of a broad range CO/H2 ratio satisfies various Fischer-Tropsch processes [1]. For example, syngas with CO/H2 ratio of 1:1, 1:2, or 1:3 can be used for gasoline, methanol, or methane production, respectively. Conventional syngas production processes, such as coal gasification and fossil reforming, are high-energy-consuming and high-energy-polluting. In this regard, the utilization of solar energy to drive CO2-to-CO and 2H+-to-H2 conversions simultaneously via an artificial photosynthetic (AP) system represents a sustainable and clean approach to syngas production [2–5]. Great effort had been devoted on developing AP systems for H2 evolution reaction (HER) or CO2 reduction reaction (CRR), independently, in the past two decades [6–19]. However, reports on photocatalytic syngas production are rare [20–32]. In the context, molecular catalysts, such as Fe-carbonyl complex [20], Fe-salen complexes [21], Co-benzotriazolate complex [22], Co(bpy)2Cl2 [23], and CoN4-complexes [24] were used in combination with noble metal complex photosensitizers (PS), such as Ir(ppy)3 and Ru(bpy)3 2+, or semiconductor PS, such as CdS nanorod and carbon nitride, for photocatalytic syngas production. However, these systems are simple physical mixing of molecular catalyst and PS, and were constructed in organic or organic/aqueous mixed solutions [20–27]. In an AP system, the distance between PS and catalyst is considered to affect much on the rate of charge transfer from the excited PS to the catalyst. Therefore, shortening distance between the PS and the catalyst through covalent bond or non-covalent methods have been applied to develop more efficient AP systems [19]. Non-covalent host-guest interaction is one of the strategies to connect two moieties typically in molecular systems. Among of many host-guest molecular building blocks, adamantane and β-cyclodextrin are extensively studied due to their good compatibility. Adamantane enables to enter hydrophobic cavity of β-cyclodextrin to form a host-guest complex. This strategy was employed to construct a hybrid photocatalytic H2 production system by Wu and co-workers recently [28]. They anchored an adamantine modified Fe2S2 catalyst onto cyclodextrin-modified CdSe QDs, based on host-guest interaction between adamantine and cyclodextrin, to achieve efficient H2 production, a 12-fold improvement of H2 production activity was obtained in comparison to the non-assembled system. However, application of the host-guest interaction strategy into hybrid photocatalytic systems, namely, system comprised by a molecular catalyst and an inorganic QDs, is still rare, especially for photocatalytic syngas production. Herein, we reported a self-assembly system of anchoring a molecular cobalt catalyst C1 onto the surface of semiconductor CuInS2/ZnS quantum dots (QDs) via host-guest interaction to realize robust photocatalytic syngas production in water (Scheme 1 ). To this end, a novel molecular catalyst C1, covalently linking an adamantine (AD) group to a [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl (TPA = tris (2-pyridylmethyl) amine) moiety, and cyclodextrin modified CuInS2/ZnS quantum dots (CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs) were design and synthesized. Cobalt (II) complexes of tetradenate nitrogen ligand (N4 ligand) as molecular catalysts had been extensively studied for electrochemical and/or photocatalytic CO2 reduction [33–35]. Among these complexes, [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl is the most robust and selective one in homogeneous photocatalytic CO2 reduction system [36–38]. We therefore chose [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl as the molecular catalytic center of CRR and designed molecular catalyst C1 for host-guest self-assembly (Scheme 1). Colloidal QDs have advantages of broad visible light absorption, larger extinction coefficient value, and high stability in comparison to molecular PS [39]. In previous studies, cadmium-based QDs, such as CdTe, CdSe, CdS, have widely used in AP systems [19,40]. However, the concern on environmental pollution of using cadmium exists. CuInS2 QDs is a kind of QDs free of cadmium. In recent studies, CuInS2 QDs and the derivatives were used to serve as a light-harvester in combination with free tetraphenylporphyrin iron(III) chloride as a catalyst for photocatalytic CO2 reduction in DMSO (solvent) [41–42]. CuInS2 QDs were also reported as a H2 production photocatalyst to catalyze protons reduction under visible light [35,41–45]. In this assembling photocatalyst of syngas production, CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs (ca. 4, 5 nm) play two roles of a light-harvester and a HER catalytic center[35,41–46] β-CD as a host moiety was modified onto the QDs to achieve self-assembly between C1 and the QDs. Based on these two components, C1 and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs, the self-assembly between them occurs in water, and C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs assemblies form successfully. Under visible light irradiation, the assemblies simultaneously convert CO2 and protons to CO and H2, respectively, in the presence of sodium ascorbate (NaHA) as an electron donor in CO2-saturated water. The catalytic activity of the system maintains 200 h, no activity ceasing was observed. The total amount of syngas production is 184.21 μmol with a CO/H2 ratio of 0.74 (ca. 2:3), corresponding to a QDs mass-based efficiency of 61.40 mmol g−1 and a turnover number of 184 based on C1. With the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs assemblies, we successfully achieved robust photocatalytic syngas production in water. The syngas production efficiency of the assemblies is higher than those of non-assembled system and system containing only CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs, demonstrating the necessity of the presence of molecular cobalt catalyst and the host-guest interaction between the cobalt catalyst and the CuInS2/ZnS QDs for efficient syngas production. 2 Synthesis and characterization 2.1 Synthesis of C1 and C2 First, the ligand L1 was synthesized by reaction of TPA-COOH with 1-adamantanemethylamine in the presence of PyBOP (Benzotriazol-1-yl-oxytripyrrolidinophosphonium hexafluorophosphate) in CH2Cl2 at room temperature (Scheme 2 ). The pure product L1 as pale-yellow powder was isolated via column chromatography and characterized by 1H NMR, 13C NMR and high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) (Electronic Supporting Information, ESI). The signals at δ = 1.55–1.99 ppm (ESI, Fig. S1) and δ = 8.90–7.13 ppm of L1 in 1H NMR spectra are attributed to the protons in adamantane and pyridines, respectively. The HRMS spectra shows a m/z peak at 482.2928, which is attributed to the [L1 + H]+ species (calculated m/z = 482.2920). The complex C1 was obtained by reaction of L1 and CoCl2•6H2O in methanol at room temperature, and the pure product C1 as green solid was obtained via precipitation by ether and washing by methanol for three cycles. A m/z peak at 575.1852 in HRMS analysis corresponds to the calculated peak at 575.1862 of [C1 - Cl]+ species. A reference complex C2 without AD group was also synthesized and characterized (ESI). UV/Vis spectrum of C1 in water (Fig. 1 a) show a strong absorption at 252 nm and a broad weak absorption in the range of 340–600 nm. These two absorptions are attributed to the π-π* absorption of the ligand and the d-d absorption of the cobalt metal complex, respectively [47]. 2.2 Synthesis of CD-CuInS2/ZnS quantum dots The β-cyclodextrin modified CuInS2/ZnS QDs (CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs) was prepared by two steps. Firstly, the precursor GSH-CuInS2/ZnS QDs (GSH = glutathione) was synthesized in an acidic aqueous solution (the synthetic details are shown in ESI) [35]. By this method, a core-shell QDs of CuInS2 as a core and ZnS as a shell were synthesized with GSH as a capping ligand. The XRD pattern of the GSH-CuInS2/ZnS QDs (ESI, Fig. S2) shows the pattern of three characteristic peaks at approximately 27.9°, 46.3° and 55.1°, which are assigned to the lattice planes of (112), (024) and (132) of CuInS2, respectively. No obvious characteristic peaks of ZnS are observed from the XRD pattern due to the low loading amount of ZnS. The GSH-CuInS2/ZnS QDs are well-dispersed in water as a brown transparent solution (ESI, Fig. S5). To achieve grafting of cyclodextrin onto the surface of CuInS2/ZnS QDs, we employed a condensation reaction between GSH-CuInS2/ZnS QDs and mono-amine-modified β-CD (β-CD-NH2) in the presence of EDC•HCl (1-(3-Dimethylaminopropyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride) as a condensation reagent. The reaction was performed in an aqueous solution in the presence of PBS (Phosphate buffered saline) at room temperature for 12 h [48]. The product CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs as red-brown powders were obtained by dialysis in water and participated by ethanol. Because of the successful grafting of cyclodextrins onto the surface of the CuInS2/ZnS QDs, the dispensability of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs in water becomes poor, and the CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs aqueous solution is a suspension (ESI, Fig. S5). FT-IR spectrum (ESI, Fig. S6) of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs shows characteristic peaks at 1029 cm−1 and 1168 cm−1, which are assigned to C-O-C stretching vibration peaks and C-O stretching vibration of cyclodextrin, respectively [49]. There is no obvious change in size and morphology of the GSH-CuInS2/ZnS QDs (ESI, Fig. S9) and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs (Fig. 1d) from TEM observation. Both two types of the QDs are mono-dispersed with an average size of ca. 4, 5 nm. The size of the GSH-CuInS2/ZnS QDs obtained is larger than the similar QDs (2.2 nm) reported by Collomb due to different synthetic procedures [35,50]. In addition, the high-magnification HRTEM images exhibited a lattice spacing of ∼0.195 nm, corresponding well to the (220) plane of CuInS2 QDs. The maximum emission peak of the GSH-CuInS2/ZnS QDs and the CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs are at 706 nm and 717 nm, respectively (ESI, Fig. S12), which show red shifts in comparison to the GSH-CuInS2/ZnS QDs obtained by Collomb group with a maximum emission peak at 638 nm [35]. Based on above results, the CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs were prepared successfully. 2.3 Self-assembly The host-guest interaction between AD and β-CD is well-known. The AD moiety can be incorporated into the cavity of β-CD with a large binding constant [28]. The anchoring of molecular cobalt catalyst onto the surface of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs is expected to achieved via the self-assembly between C1 and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs. The self-assembly between C1 and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs was conducted by ultrasonic treatment a mixture of C1 and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs in water at room temperature. The UV/Vis spectrum of the mixture solution shows the characteristic absorption of C1 at 252 nm. After 8 h of ultrasonic treatment, obvious red-brown precipitations emerged in the solution. The UV/Vis spectrum of the supernatant shows no characteristic absorption of C1 (Fig. 1b), indicating molecular catalysts assemble to the QDs thus leads precipitation. The precipitations were isolated and analyzed by FT-IR measurements (Fig. 1c). The FT-IR spectra of the precipitations shows a set of characteristic peaks at 2908 cm−1, 2846 cm−1, 1610 cm−1, 1309 cm−1 and 767 cm−1, which are also observed in the IR spectra of C1 (Fig. 1c). Among them, the peaks at 2908 cm−1 and 2846 cm−1 are attributed to the C-H bond vibration of C1, and the peaks at 1610 cm−1, 1309 cm−1 and 767 cm−1 are attributed to the pyridine vibration of C1 [51–53]. These results indicate that the host-guest interaction between C1 and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs operates, and the successful loading of C1 onto the surface of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs occurs. The morphology of the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs assemblies was characterized by TEM. The TEM image (Fig. 1e) of the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs sample show that QDs are aggregated and showing tube-like morphology. Confocal measurement (Fig. 1f) of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs aqueous solution shows small emissive dots in the merged and green channel images. However, the confocal image (Fig. 1g) of the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs aqueous solution show large aggregations. No obvious emissions were found due to the quenching in the presence of C1 (discussed below). The morphology of the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs assemblies in TEM and confocal images are not as same as the expectation that C1 are attached onto the surface of QDs by only terminal AD groups. We speculate that C1 can be bound with β-CD by either AD group or pyridine group. In this way, C1 functions as a linker to induce QDs aggregation. We used UV/Vis absorption titration (ESI, Fig. S15) and HRMS to confirm this hypothesis. By increasing the concentration of β-CD-NH2, the characteristic absorption at 380 nm of C1 in an aqueous solution increases. This is attributed to the host-guest interaction between β-CD-NH2 and AD group in C1. Namely, the AD group in C1 enters the cavity of β-CD-NH2. The binding constant K 1 is 2.62 × 106 M−1, which is calculated according to method in literature [54]. We chose [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl as a model complex to verify if it can be partially incorporated by β-CD. It was found that the absorption at 380 nm of [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl also increases as increasing the concentration of β-CD-NH2. As reported in literature, the size of the partial moiety of [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl single crystal is 4.6–5.6 Å (ESI, Fig. S16), which is smaller than the cavity diameter (6.0–6.5 Å) of β-CD [55,56]. It is reasonable to attribute the absorption increase of [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl in the presence of β-CD-NH2 to partial inclusion of [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl into the cavity of β-CD-NH2. The binding constant K 2 is 5.61 × 105 M−1. The value of K2 is smaller than K1 , indicating weaker interaction of the incorporation between β-CD-NH2 and [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl. HRMS spectrum (ESI, Fig. S17) of C1 and β-CD-NH2 mixed solution showed three attributable m/z peaks at 1134.3961, 1403.9988 and 1672.5956. The peak at 1134.3961 and 1672.5956 are assigned to the fragment of β-CD-NH2 and C1@β-CD-NH2, respectively (see ESI). The peak at 1403.9988 represents a fragment of [C1 + 2(β-CD-NH2)], indicating the existence of C1@2(β-CD-NH2) assembly. All these evidences indicate that C1 can be included into the cavity of β-CD-NH2 through two binding sites, AD group and [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl moiety. 2.4 Photocatalytic syngas production A photocatalytic sample containing C1 (0.02 mM) as a molecular catalyst, CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs (0.30 mg mL−1) as a PS, and sodium ascorbate (0.015 M) as an electron donor was constructed in CO2-saturated water (10.00 mL). The sample was irradiated under a blue LED lamp for 15 h at room temperature. The gaseous products were analyzed by gas chromatography. As shown in Fig. 2 a, the sample produced 5.59 μmol CO and 22.91 μmol H2, the CO/H2 ratio is ca. 1:4. Control experiments showed that lacking of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs, NaHA, or light irradiation, the sample produced none to trace syngas (H2 + CO). The system in a N2-saturated solution produced only 0.42 μmol CO and 29.31 μmol H2. At the same conditions, the sample without C1 produced only 0.50 μmol CO and 16.89 μmol H2. To study the role of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs, CD-CuInS2 and CD-ZnS nanocrystals were also prepared and characterized by XRD (ESI, Figs. S3 and S4) and TEM (ESI, Figs. S10 and S11). The CD-CuInS2 without ZnS shell shows poor crystallinity. CD-CuInS2 and CD-ZnS are nanocrystals with a size of ca. 3, 4 nm and ca. 3–6 nm, respectively. By using CD-CuInS2 QDs to replace CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs, the sample C1@CD-CuInS2 produced 0.21 μmol CO and 3.25 μmol H2, while the pristine CD-CuInS2 sample produced only 0.09 μmol CO and 6.06 μmol H2 at the same condition. The pristine ZnS produced 0.12 μmol CO and 0.46 μmol H2. These results demonstrate that C1 mainly functions as a CO formation center and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs functions as a light-harvester and a major site for H2 evolution. The core-shell structure of the CD-CuInS2/ZnS is crucial for the high photocatalytic activity of the system. CuInS2 demonstrated higher activity on H2 production in comparison to ZnS. ZnS existing as a thin shell improves crystallinity of the CuInS2 core, which is evidenced by XRD measurements and TEM images (ESI, Figs. S2 and S9). All of the above findings indicate that all these components, molecular catalyst, CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs, NaHA, CO2 and light irradiation, are essential for syngas production. The host-guest interaction between C1 and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs enhances CO production activity and selectivity of the system. By using C2 to replace C1, the CO production amount decreased to 2.66 μmol, however, the H2 production amount of 21.55 μmol changes slightly. By using GSH-CuInS2/ZnS QDs to replace CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs, the system produced only 3.99 μmol CO and 27.83 μmol H2. In these two cases, the strong host-guest interaction between AD and CD vanishes, molecular catalyst C2 (in former case) or C1 (in latter case) is free in solution. Therefore, CO production amount decreases in both cases, but H2 production amount does not change obviously. These results demonstrate that the tightly attachment of molecular cobalt catalysts onto the surface of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs improves CO formation activity and selectivity of the system. The pH effect and component concentration effect of the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs system were investigated. As shown in Fig. 2b, the system exhibits pH-dependent activity on syngas production. The system produced highest amount syngas of 26.45–27.01 μmol at pH 6.0–10.0, the CO/H2 ratio is in the range of 0.22–0.24. At acidic condition of pH 4.0, the syngas production amount decreased to 17.95 μmol, and the CO/H2 ratio also decreased to only 0.09. The system is prone to produce H2 at acidic condition. At alkaline condition of pH 12.0, the syngas production amount decreased slightly to 23.02 μmol, however, the CO/H2 ratio increased to 0.48. This indicates that CO2 reduction reaction is kinetically favorable at alkaline condition. For the component concentration effect, in one hand, by improving C1 concentration from 2.00 × 10−5 M to 5.00 × 10−4 M, the syngas production amount increased from 28.50 μmol to 81.92 μmol, demonstrating the catalytic role for syngas formation of the molecular catalyst. The highest CO/H2 ratio of 0.51 was obtained at C1 concentration of 1.00 × 10−4 M (ESI, Fig. S18). In another hand, by improving concentration of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs from 0.3 to 0.9 mg mL−1, the total amount of syngas production increased from 28.50 to 54.84 μmol. However, the CO/H2 ratio decreased from 0.24 to 0.18 (ESI, Fig. S19). This further indicates that CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs is prone to mediate H2 formation. Based on above results, a sample at the optimal conditions, namely, C1 at 1.00 × 10−4 M and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs at 0.3 mg mL−1 in pH 12.0 aqueous solution, was irradiated to estimate the stability. As shown in Fig. 2c, d, the system shows excellent stability of syngas production. No syngas production activity ceasing was found during 200 h of irradiation. The total amount of syngas production achieves to 184.21 μmol. The syngas production efficiency is 61.40 mmol g−1 based on CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs mass and the turnover number is 184 based on C1. The CO/H2 ratio is 0.74 at the end of the photocatalysis. However, the CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs system without cobalt catalyst C1 produced only 87.93 μmol syngas with a CO/H2 ratio of 0.27. Both syngas production amount and CO/H2 ratio improve more than two-fold in the presence of C1, demonstrating the important role of the molecular cobalt catalyst C1. To reveal stability of the system, the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis of cobalt content was conducted before and after 100 h irradiation of the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS system. It was found that the cobalt content of the sample changes slightly from 2.91 × 10−7 mol mg−1 before photocatalysis to 2.70 × 10−7 mol mg−1 after 100 h irradiation. 2.5 Photoinduced electron transfer To gain insight into the system, static quenching experiments (Fig. 3 a) were performed. The photoluminescence of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs at λmax = 717 nm (λex = 450 nm) can be efficiently quenched by successively adding C1 or C2. The average lifetime of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs recorded at 760 nm (λex = 485 nm) is 85 ns. There is no overlap between the UV/Vis absorption spectrum of C1 or C2 and the PL spectrum of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs (Fig. 1a and ESI, Fig. S20), the quenching is attributed to the photoinduced electron transfer (PET) from CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs to C1 or C2. According to Stern-Volumer equation, the quenching constant kPET of C1 or C2 is 2.26 × 1012 M−1 s−1 or 1.73 × 1012 M−1 s−1, respectively (Fig. 3b and ESI, Fig. S21). The former is larger than that of the latter. The difference of the kPET between two complexes, C1 and C2, is due to their structural feature. The adamantane group in C1 enters hydrophobic cavity of β-CD on the surface of the QDs, this hybrid structural configuration shortens distance between the QDs and the catalyst and thus leads a faster PET. However, C2 without an adamantane group encounters the QDs via an intermolecular way. The host-guest interaction between the adamantane in C1 and β-CD on CuInS2/ZnS QD play an important role on mediating efficient electron transfer from the QD to the cobalt center of C1. Transient photocurrent responses (TPR) of the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs were measured in a photoelectrochemical cell by using FTO glass, Pt wire, and SCE as working electrode, counter electrode and reference electrode, respectively. The measurements were carried out in an aqueous solution in the presence of Na2SO4 as an electrolyte and Xe lamp (λ > 420 nm) as a light source. As shown in Fig. 3c, the CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs electrode showed a TPR of 118 nA cm−2. The TPR is stable in the whole measurement time (400 s). After that, the CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs electrode was immersed in an aqueous solution of C1 for 30 min and dried at 60 °C. The TPR of the C1 treatment electrode increased to 450 nA cm−2, a 3.8-fold improvement was obtained. This result indicates that the electron-hole recombination in CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs is inhibited through fast PET from QDs to C1 under visible light irradiation. The free energy change (ΔG0 ) of the PET process in the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs was estimated according to Rehm-Weller equation. Firstly, the cyclic voltammogram of C1 was measured (Fig. 3d). Upon reductive scan in nitrogen atmosphere, two redox events of an irreversible peak at Epc = -1.27 V (all potentials discussed here are vs. NHE) and a quasi-reversible peak at E1/2 = -1.49 V were observed. The current intensity of the first reductive peak increases in CO2 atmosphere, indicating the electrocatalysis of CO2 occurs at the first reductive event. According to previous studies, these two reductive peaks are attributed to the CoII/I and CoI/0 couples, respectively, of C1 [34]. The conduction bond potential -1.47 V of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs was estimated by Mott-Schottky measurements (ESI, Figs. S22 and S23). The free energy change of the PET process, namely, electron transfer from conduction bond of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs to the cobalt center of C1, is estimated as -0.20 eV, indicating this is a thermodynamically feasible process. 2.6 Mechanism Based on above results, a mechanism of photocatalytic syngas production by the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs assemblies is proposed (Scheme 3 ). Under visible light irradiation, CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs is excited to generate electron-hole pairs, and then these electrons and holes migrate to the surface of the QDs. A portion of electrons transfer from the QDs to C1 at surface of the QDs to generate a CoI species. The CoI species as an active site binds a CO2 to afford CO [7–9,57]. Another portion of electrons participate protons reduction occurring at surface of the QDs to generate H2. Holes in the QDs are consumed by ascorbate. According to photocatalytic experiments results, the major center of CRR and HER of the assemblies is C1 and the QDs, respectively. The CuInS2/ZnS QDs functions not only a light-harvester but also a HER catalytic center [35,41–46]. The specific host-guest strategy of anchoring active molecular catalyst on the surface of CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs improves CRR selectivity of the system as well as enhances PET between the QDs and C1. The system exhibits supra-long lifetime for syngas production, which is seldom observed from molecular catalyst-based AP systems [19]. We speculate that the interaction between CD of CD-CuInS2/ZnS and [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl moiety of C1, namely, partial incorporation of the [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl moiety into CD cavity, protects and stabilize C1 during photocatalysis [29]. 3 Conclusion In conclusion, the host-guest interaction strategy was successfully applied to construct a self-assembly hybrid photocatalyst C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs of anchoring molecular cobalt catalysts onto CuInS2/ZnS QDs. The C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs assemblies enable to simultaneously convert CO2-to-CO and 2H+-to-H2 in a CO2-saturated aqueous solution in the presence of sodium ascorbate as electron donor under visible light irradiation, and can be used for artificial photosynthetic syngas production. In the assemblies, C1 is the major catalyst for CRR, and CuInS2/ZnS QDs functions as both the HER catalytic center and the light-harvester. Mechanism studies revealed that photoinduced electron transfer from CuInS2/ZnS QDs to C1 occurs. At optimal condition, the assemblies produced 184.21 μmol syngas with a CO/H2 ratio of 0.74, and showed outstanding stability that keeping syngas production activity more than 200 h. Thanks to the host-guest interaction, the C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs assemblies showed obvious advantages of syngas production efficiency and CO selectivity in comparison to the non-assembled system and pristine CuInS2/ZnS QDs system, showing a paradigm of tuning catalytic activity and selectivity of semiconductor nanoparticle photocatalysts via surface manipulation of non-covalent anchoring molecular catalytic sites. coredata.dc:description: Simultaneously fulfilling CO2-to-CO and 2H+-to-H2 reactions in water via photocatalyst represents an alternative to produce syngas driven by solar energy. To this end, photocatalyst having ability of simultaneously producing CO and H2 with controllable ratio should be exploited. In this work, we report a self-assembly photocatalyst C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS quantum dots (QDs) that enabling to produce syngas robustly in CO2-saturated water under visible light irradiation. C1 is a molecular catalyst of linking an adamantine moiety to [Co(TPA)Cl]Cl (TPA = tris (2-pyridylmethyl) amine), while CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs are semiconductor QDs with structure of CuInS2 core and ZnS shell and containing β-cyclodextrin (CD) on the surface. The C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs assemblies form by anchoring molecular cobalt catalyst C1 onto cyclodextrin (CD) modified CuInS2/ZnS quantum dots (CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs) based on host-guest interaction between adamantine in C1 and cyclodextrin in the QDs. In which, C1 functions a molecular catalytic center mainly for CO2 reduction, and CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs functions as both a light harvester and a hydrogen production center. The C1@CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs system maintains syngas production activity over 200 h, and produces 184.21 μmol syngas with a CO/H2 ratio of 0.74 (ca. 2:3), exhibiting obvious advantages of syngas production efficiency in comparison to the non-assembled system and pristine CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs system. Mechanism studies revealed that photoinduced electron transfer between CD-CuInS2/ZnS QDs and C1 occurs. The host-guest interaction improves syngas production activity and stability as well as plays positive role on stability of the molecular catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Host-guest assemblies of anchoring molecular catalysts of CO2 reduction onto CuInS2/ZnS quantum dots for robust photocatalytic syngas production in water
